GfxUtility Class Reference

This static class contains a lot of utility-methods about geographical data. More...

Detailed Description

This static class contains a lot of utility-methods about geographical data.

See also:
Utility.h Non-geographic utility-methods.

Definition at line 41 of file GfxUtility.h.

Member Enumeration Documentation

enum GfxUtility::coordianteRepresentations
 

The types of text representation of a lat or lon in printLatLon.

Enumeration values:
simpleRad  simpleRad, 13.1911N, precision is number decimals.

The coordinate is expressed in decimal degrees with a final letter for compass direction (N|S|W|E or N|S|V|Ö ...).

wgs84Style  wgs84 style, N 13° 19' 12.96", precision is number decimals.

The coordinate is expressed as: compass direction degreesï¿½ minutes' seconds".

wgs84Rad  wgs84Rad The coordinate is expressed in radians.
wgs84Deg  wgs84Deg The coordinate is expressed in decimal degrees.
nmea  NMEA.

void GfxUtility::calcArrowPoints (  POINT *  src,
POINT *  dst,
POINT *  arrow,
int32  cornerDistance,
int32  shortDistance,
int32  longDistance,
bool  addCenterPoint,
int32  arrowLength,
int32  angle,
bool  useCosLat = true
)  [static]
 

Calculates an turn arrow.

NB documentation is reverse enginered from source.

         the turn  
                  |\¯¯¯¯¯¯¯¯¯¯¯¯¯ after turn
                  | \ cornerDist
                  |  \   angle \ ¯ arrowLength
                  |   \    /¯¯¯/ ¯
                  |    \  /\   
                  |     \/
                  |     /\  shortDistance
                  |    /
                  |   /  
                  |   |  longDistance 
                  |   |_
     before turn  |

Parameters:
src The three turn points, before turn, the turn and finally after turn.
dst Set to the four(five if addCenterPoint) spline control points of the turn arrow line, see addCenterPoint.
arrow Set to the three points of the arrow, left, center and then right.
cornerDistance How far out the turn arrow line should be.
pointDistance1 Distance before center of spline.
pointDistance2 Distance after center of spline.
addCenterPoint If the center of the spline should be added to dst after the first two spline control points.
arrowLength The length of the arrow.
angle The angle of the arrow.
useCosLat If the horisontal lengths should be cossine adjusted, default true.

float64 GfxUtility::calcRadius (  int32  lat0,
int32  lon0,
int32  lat1,
int32  lon1,
int32  lat2,
int32  lon2
)  [static]
 

Calculate the radius of a circle given three coordinates (on the circle border).

Parameters:
lat0 The first latitude on the circle border.
lon0 The first longitude on the circle border.
lat1 The second latitude on the circle border.
lon1 The second longitude on the circle border.
lat2 The third latitude on the circle border.
lon2 The third longitude on the circle border.
Returns:
The radius in mc2-units of the circle. MAX_UINT32 if no radius could be calculated (ie. infinite radius).

int GfxUtility::cleanSelfintersecting (  vector< vector< MC2Coordinate > > &  polygons  )  throw (MC2Exception) [static]
 

Removes self-intersections.

Will fill holes in falukorvs. Currently copies all the coordinates into vectors of POINT, runs cleanSelfintersecting and then copies the result back.

int GfxUtility::clipPolylineToBBox (  const MC2BoundingBox &  bbox,
vector< vector< POINT > > &  polygons
)  [static]
 

Clips the first polyline (open polygon) in the polygons vector against the boundingbox.

Parameters:
bbox The boundingbox to clip against.
polygons [IN/OUT] The first polygon of the vector is the polygon that will be clipped. The resulting polygons will be added to the vector, replacing the original polygon.
Returns:
The number of resulting polygons.

bool GfxUtility::clipPolyToBBoxFast (  const MC2BoundingBox *  bbox,
vector< POINT > &  vertices
)  [static]
 

Clips the specifed closed polygon to a boundingbox and adds it to the clippedGfxData.

The polygon is clipped by first reducing the number of vertices outside the boundingbox, and then Sutherland-Hodgeman clipping is performed.

Note that the result is always a single polygon, even if the polygon to be clipped is concave. This is the drawback of using this method.

Parameters:
bbox The boundingbox to clip the polygon to.
vertices [IN/OUT] The polygon to be clipped.
Returns:
True if the resulting clipped polygon is not empty, false otherwise.

void GfxUtility::clipSegment (  const POINT &  prevVertex,
const POINT &  currVertex,
bool  prevInside,
bool  currInside,
byte  currOutcode,
const MC2BoundingBox *  bbox,
byte  boundaryOutcode,
vector< byte > &  resOutcodes,
vector< POINT > &  resVertices
)  [static, private]
 

Help-method to clipToBoundary(..).

Clips the two vertices against the boundary of a boundingbox.

Parameters:
prevVertex The previous vertex.
currVertex The next vertex.
prevInside If prevVertex is inside the bbox boundary.
currInside If currVertex is inside the bbox boundary.
currOutcode The Cohen-Sutherland outcode of currVertex.
bbox The boundingbox.
boundaryOutcode The Cohen-Sutherland outcode of boundary of the boundingbox to clip to, ie. MC2BoundingBox::TOP/BOTTOM/LEFT/RIGHT
resVertices The resulting clipped vertices are added to this vector.
resOutcodes The resulting outcodes of the clipped vertices are added to this vector.

bool GfxUtility::clipToBoundary (  const byte  boundaryOutcode,
const MC2BoundingBox *  bbox,
vector< POINT > &  vertices,
vector< byte > &  outcodes,
vector< POINT > &  resVertices,
vector< byte > &  resOutcodes
)  [static, private]
 

Clip the vertices against a boundary of a boundingbox.

Part of the Sutherland-Hodgeman clipping algorithm.

Parameters:
boundaryOutcode The Cohen-Sutherland outcode of boundary of the boundingbox to clip to, ie. MC2BoundingBox::TOP/BOTTOM/LEFT/RIGHT
bbox The boundingbox.
vertices Vector of the vertices to clip. The vector is cleared afterwards.
outcodes Vector of the outcodes of the vertices to clip. The vector is cleared afterwards.
resVertices The resulting clipped vertices are added to this vector.
resOutcodes The resulting outcodes of the clipped vertices are added to this vector.
Returns:
True if the resulting clipped vertices is a valid polygon, false otherwise.

int GfxUtility::clipToPolygon (  const MC2BoundingBox &  bbox,
vector< vector< POINT > > &  polygons
)  [static]
 

Clips the first polygon in the polygons vector against the boundingbox.

The algorithm used is described in: "Efficient Clipping of Arbitrary polygons:" by Gunther Greiner and Kai Hormann from Computer Graphics Group, University of Erlangen.

The algorithm handles selfintersecting polygons, and can result in multiple clipped polygons, in case the polygon to be clipped is concave.

Before clipping is performed, the number of vertices outside the boundingbox is reduced and the vertices are slightly perturbed so that no the polygon to be clipped does not contain any coordinates on the clip polygon boundary.

Parameters:
bbox The boundingbox to clip against.
polygons [IN/OUT] The first polygon of the vector is the polygon that will be clipped. The resulting polygons will be added to the vector, replacing the original polygon. The input polygon must also be closed.
Returns:
The number of resulting polygons.

int GfxUtility::clipToPolygon (  const vector< POINT > &  clipPolygon,
vector< vector< POINT > > &  polygons
)  [static]
 

Clips the first polygon in the polygons vector against the clipPolygon.

The algorithm used is described in: "Efficient Clipping of Arbitrary polygons:" by Gunther Greiner and Kai Hormann from Computer Graphics Group, University of Erlangen.

The algorithm handles selfintersecting polygons, and can result in multiple clipped polygons, in case the polygon to be clipped is concave.

The polygon to be clipped may not have coordinates that are touching a clip border.

Parameters:
clipPolygon The polygon containing the polygon to clip against. The polygon must be closed, i.e. the first and last coordinate must be the same.
polygons [IN/OUT] The first polygon of the vector is the polygon that will be clipped. The resulting polygons will be added to the vector, replacing the original polygon. The input polygon must also be closed.
Returns:
The number of resulting polygons.

uint64 GfxUtility::closestDistVectorToPoint (  int32  x1,
int32  y1,
int32  x2,
int32  y2,
int32  xpos,
int32  ypos,
int32 &  xOut,
int32 &  yOut,
double  cosF
)  [static]
 

Calculate the closest distance from a vector (defined by (x1,y1) and (x2,y2) ) to a point (xpos, ypos) and also the point, on the line between (x1,y1) and (x2,y2), which is closest to (xpos, ypos).

Parameters:
x1 The x-part of the first coordinate of the vector.
y1 The y-part of the first coordinate of the vector.
x2 The x-part of the second coordinate of the vector.
y2 The y-part of the second coordinate of the vector.
xpos The x-part of the point to calculate distance to.
ypos The y-part of the point to calculate distance to.
xOut Outparameter that is set to the x-part of the coordinate that are closest to (xpos, ypos)
xOut Outparameter that is set to the y-part of the coordinate that are closest to (xpos, ypos)
cosF The cosine factor.
Returns:
The minimum distance to (xpos, ypos) from vector

Calculate the closest distance from a vector (defined by (x1,y1) and (x2,y2) ) to a point (xpos, ypos).

Parameters:

y1 The y-part of the first coordinate of the vector.
x2 The x-part of the second coordinate of the vector.
y2 The y-part of the second coordinate of the vector.
xpos The x-part of the point to calculate distance to.
ypos The y-part of the point to calculate distance to.
cosF The cosine factor.
Returns:
The minimum distance to (xpos, ypos) from vector.

float64 GfxUtility::convertToDrawAngle (  float64  angleFromNorth  )  [static]
 

float64 GfxUtility::convLatLonStringToDbl (  const char *  s  )  [static]
 

Convert a string containing a SWEREF93 latitude or longitude to a SWEREF93 radians coordinate.

The input string would look like D(D*).ddd(N/S/E/W).

Parameters:
s The null terminated lat or lon string in the format specified by WGS 84.
Returns:
An float64 in SWEREF93 radians.

int32 GfxUtility::convLatLonStringToInt (  const char *  s  )  [static]
 

Convert a string containing WGS 84 latitude or longitude to an MC2 integer coordinate.

The input string would look like (N/S/E/W) D(D*)MMSS[.ddd], that is the period and the following numbers are optional.

Parameters:
s The null terminated lat or lon string in the format specified by WGS 84.
Returns:
An integer representing the position in the MC2 coordinate system.

void GfxUtility::generatePointInMap (  int32  y1,
int32  x1,
int32  y2,
int32  x2,
int32 &  yOut,
int32 &  xOut
)  [static]
 

Method used to determine to which map a given segement shall belong to, if the given segment is on the boundary between two maps.

Parameters:
(y1,x1) Lat-lon coordinates of one endpoint of the segment.
(y2,x2) Lat-lon coordinates of the second endpoint of the segment.
(yOut,xOut) Outparameters. Lat-lon coordinates of a point not lying on the given segment, and such that points (y1,x1) (y2,x2) (yOut,xOut) are clockwise oriented

void GfxUtility::getAdjacentRectangle (  const MC2BoundingBox *  bbox,
int32  lat,
int32  lon,
int &  vertPos,
int &  horPos
)  [static]
 

Finds out where a given point is located relative a given bounding box.

The sides of the bounding box is virtually extended so there are nine rectangles (eight unbounded ones) including the bounding box itself.

Parameters:
bbox Bounding box used.
(lat,lon) Point to determine the location for.
vertPos Outparameter. Vertical position of (lat,lon). Can have the values -1, 0 or 1:
-1: Somewhere below the bounding box 0: Inside, left or right of the bounding box 1: Somewhere above the bounding box

Parameters:
horPos Outparameter. Vertical position of (lat,lon). Can have the values -1, 0 or 1:
-1: Somewhere to the left of the bounding box 0: Inside, above or below the bounding box 1: Somewhere to the right of the bounding box

float64 GfxUtility::getAngleFromNorth (  const MC2Coordinate &  first,
const MC2Coordinate &  second
)  [static]
 

see the other getAngleFromNorth function.

float64 GfxUtility::getAngleFromNorth (  int32  lat1,
int32  lon1,
int32  lat2,
int32  lon2,
bool  useCosLat = true
)  [static]
 

Get the angle from the north-direction.

Used to calculate the angle described by the figure: 

                      (lat2, lon2)
                  |     /
                  |    /
                  |   /
                  |A /
                  |\/
                  |/ (lat1, lon1)
                  |
                  |
                  |

Parameters:
lat1 The latitude of the startpoint for the line.
lon1 The longitude of the startpoint for the line.
lat2 The latitude of the endpoint for the line.
lon2 The longitude of the endpoint for the line.
Returns:
Angle in radians from the north-direction in clockwise direction. The return value is in the interval $[0,2[$.

int32  lat2,
int32  lon2
)  [static]

)  [static]
 

Calculates the aspect correct view of an arc.

Parameters:
minLat Upper left latitude of boundingbox.
minLon Upper left longitude of boundingbox.
maxLat Lower right latitude of boundingbox.
maxLon Lower right longitude of boundingbox.
width The width of the display.
height The height of the display.
lat The center of arc.
lon The center of arc.
innerRadius The inner radius.
outerRadius The outer radius.
startAngle The start angle in degrees.
stopAngle The stop angle in degrees.
cx Set center of arc x-value, may be negative or larger than height.
cy Set center of arc y-value, may be negative or larger than height.
iR Set to the inner radius.
oR Set to the outer radius.

int32  y1,

)  [static]
 

Determines the part of a given line segment, (x1,y1) to (x2,y2), that is inside a given rectangle.

Parameters:
(x1,y1) one endpoint in line segment to be clipped
(x2,y2) second endpoint in line segment to be clipped
minX x-coordinate of the left veritical edge in rectangle
maxX x-coordinate of the right veritical edge in rectangle
minY y-coordinate of the lower horisontal edge in rectangle
maxY y-coordinate of the upper horisontaledge in rectangle
(x1Out,y1Out) outparameter one endpoint in clipped line segment
(x2Out,y2Out) outparameter second endpoint in clipped line segment
Returns:
true if at least one point of the line segment is inside the rectangle, false otherwise

bool GfxUtility::getIntersection (  int32  x1,
int32  y1,
int32  x2,
int32  y2,
int32  v1,
int32  w1,
int32  v2,
int32  w2,
int32 &  intersectX,
int32 &  intersectY,
float64 *  percentFromx1y1,
float64 *  percentFromv1w1
)  [static, private]
 

Find the intersection between two lines that can be described by the following coordinates: Line 1: (x1, y1) - (x2, y2) and \ Line 2: (v1, w1) - (v2, w2).

Parameters:
x1 x1 coordinate of line 1.
y1 y1 coordinate of line 1.
x2 x2 coordinate of line 1.
y2 y2 coordinate of line 1.
v1 v1 coordinate of line 2.
w1 w1 coordinate of line 2.
v2 v2 coordinate of line 2.
w2 w2 coordinate of line 2.
intersectX Output parameter set to the x coordinate of the intersection of the two lines.
intersectY Output parameter set to the y coordinate of the intersection of the two lines.
percentFromx1y1 [Output] If not NULL, how many percent between (x1,y1) and (x2,y2) the intersection lies.
percentFromv1w1 [Output] If not NULL, how many percent between (v1,w1) and (v2,w2) the intersection lies.
Returns:
True if the two lines intersects each other, false otherwise.

bool GfxUtility::getPointOnLine (  int32  lat1,
int32  lon1,
int32  lat2,
int32  lon2,
float64  dist,
float64  totDist,
int32 &  outLat,
int32 &  outLon
)  [static]
 

Get a point located dist meters from (lat1,lon1) and on the line from (lat1,lon1) to (lat2,lon2).

Will return false if the distance from (lat1,lon1) to (lat2,lon2) is less than dist.

Use this method if the distance between (lat1,lon1) and (lat2,lon2) already is calculated.

Parameters:
lat1 Latitude part of the first point on the line.
lon1 Longitude part of the first point on the line.
lat2 Latitude part of the second point on the line.
lon2 Longitude part of the second point on the line.
dist The distance from (lat1,lon1) of the returned coordinate.
outLat Outparameter that is set to the coordinate described above.
outLon Outparameter that is set to the coordinate described above.
Returns:
True if the outparameters are updated, false otherwise.

int  y2,
int  x3,
int  y3,
vector< int > &  resX,
vector< int > &  resY,

double *  endAngle = NULL
)  [static]
 

Draws a spline.

Parameters:
x0 The x value of the first controlpoint.
y0 The y value of the first controlpoint.
x1 The x value of the second controlpoint.
y1 The y value of the second controlpoint.
x2 The x value of the third controlpoint.
y2 The y value of the third controlpoint.
x3 The x value of the fourth controlpoint.
y3 The y value of the fourth controlpoint.
resX The vector to insert x values into.
resY The vector to insert y values into.
bias The amount to move along the spline between each sample, default 0.02 (1/50 50 points along the curve). The bias must be in the range ]0.0,1.0].
endAngle Set to the angle at the endpoint of the spline if endAngle is not NULL.

int32  minY,
int32  maxY
)  [static]
 

Checks if two points are located on the same boundary of a given rectangle.

If the two points are equal, the method is used to determine if a given point is located somewhere on the rectangular boundary.

Parameters:

(x2,y2) Second point to check

maxX x-coordinate of right vertical edge in rectangle
minY y-coordinate of lower horizontal edge.

Returns:
